messages.text: in case of sigmoid activation function do we set any threshold to classify values or we just got for event vs non event case
@durgesh2987 in case of sigmoid - then you'll make decision, what probability %% makes it
in case of softmax - just the biggest one typically
@raver119 for example if probality in sigmoid for event is 0.2 and non event is 0.8 so we choose non event but how we say  non event is not our target class?

> but how we say non event is not our target class?

can you rephrase please? i can't understand what exactly you're asking

@durgesh2987  I believe what you wish to do here is in case of classification, the sigmoid function provides a ayesian probability, but you would like to define a threshold based on which you would like to decide which class the network has given ( e.g.: if it is a class is at least 0.8, then it is the target class ).

 Please note, that a network might not always return big confidence values, so a fixed threshold, like e.g. 0.8 might not always lead to a correct solution. If I understood correctly, that is what the softmax function is for exactly: it gives back the class with the highest possibility.

@davids91  @raver119  In case of binary classification using sigmoid for output layer the output probabilities for true event and non true event need not necessary sum up to one?? For example Class A has a probability 0.3 and class NonA has probaility 0.2 then prediction would be class A
@durgesh2987 SIgmoid doesn't enforce that rule, a SoftMax layer does.
Why is there an activationFunction in LossLayers?
oh wait I get it, please disregard my previous question

@durgesh2987 you're mixing softmax and sigmoid here. in case of sigmoid your individual outputs are considered independent like when you're doing classification when each entity might belong to multiple classes at the same time
so you're just framing this in wrong way
Hi, If I had normalized my input data, can my Network (regression) predicts me values outside of the normalization range ? i.e. input [0;1] output [-1.5;2.5]
If the network gave me values between -1.5 and 2.5, does it mean that I have a problem with my (input) normalization process, or the network can gave me these values (I don't think so ...)

@bastienjalbert I'm not following... do you mean you normalized your outputs to that [-1.5, 2.5] range?
at any rate, normalization doesn't guarantee your predictions will be in a specific range
the net - if properly learning - should learn to predict within the normalized range. So, it'll be close, but not exact
only way to guarantee output in a specific range exactly is via the activation function... for example sigmoid (0 to 1) or tanh (-1 to 1)

so inputs normalized [0;1], LSTM network with only tanh or sigmoid (+ dense final layer), and I get outputs between (approx.) [-1.5; 2.5] (only if I try to predict all 5 labels, with 1 it's ok). So can the output of my network be within [-1.5; 2.5] if ALL my input data are normalized between 0 and 1 ? I don't think so, but when I look to my input data, they seems correct (all between 0 & 1) ... Can you confirm me if my problem comes from the way I normalize or if my network outputs can be outside of input normalization range :) ?
I hope I'm clear ...

> if my network outputs can be outside of input normalization range

input normalization and output values aren't linked in the way you seem to think they are
other than difficulty optimizing the network (which is why we normalize), inputs could be in any range, outputs could be in any other range
Thank you for your answer

15000 data sets, how many epochs are suitable for training

@Shixuebin there's no simple answer
it depends on the network, dataset, minibatch size and tuning
some (probably too small) networks will converge in less than 1 epoch
others with poor tuning will never converge
just track performance of your model over time
and/or use early stopping
http://deeplearning4j.org/docs/latest/deeplearning4j-nn-early-stopping

Question, have a dataset in the following format:
`x1 y1 z1 yaw1 pitch1 attackTypeOrdinal, x2 y2 z2 yaw2 pitch2 attackTypeOrdinal`

Here is an example of the layout:
`1 2 3 4 5 3, 1 2 3 4 5 3`

What I was planning on doing is having separated lists of those pairs in order for the machine to find patterns off of, what is the best way to do this?

PS: The attackTypeOrdinal is the same for the entire pair
@camdenorrb  you need to design a lost function accordingly.
lost function?
Also it might be good to note that I plan to train this on the fly, rather than having set values in a file
Oh, Loss Function?
you can do this on the fly as long as you put them into a DataSetIterator,
but if the training data change, you will need to retrain your model
so the best thing to do is getting the training data ready before you start this process
That won't be possible, in this case
It will need to be improved with the more information we give it
.....normally you can wait until you get enough "on the fly" data
Yes, we can wait for one input, but we can't wait for all inputs
Would I still need to retrain the entire model each time?
I think you get the idea wrong.
Hm?
you have assume that the pattern doesn't change, so that you can train a network and then apply it on the other data.
in this case, you need to wait and get a training set first
Yeah we can wait for individual training sets
But we can't provide them all at once
once you happy with the result, you can then use the model on other data
so you expect the machine learn the pattern based on one date?
No, I expect it to be able to learn on different dates
It won't get it down the first time we give it a training set
so you need to get these different dates first before it can learn
It will take a-lot more
Also since I'm taking 2, 6 parameter inputs how can I link 2 loss functions?
Or "classify" it
you try to get the patterns between these two inputs right?
Alright, let me explain
So basically I will take in around 100 pairs of those 2 inputs in each training session and the goal is to find the pattern in a 10 pair input
The pair references each other
This data will be used to classify what type of pattern it is, which will be trained
I'm not sure if this is the best way to do it or if it's even possible
Does it make sense?
what types of pattern you expect to get from this task? could you give me an example?
So in this case it's to classify if a player is a hacker or not
I see
It has to determine it quickly, hence the 10 input idea
It will be trained with a ton of datasets tho

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g2YBWQnqOpw

Hi, I am puzzling how can we preprocess the time series for LSTM? the feature of time is long type (like 1466572418), and the value is increasing all the time, do we need to transform it to a certain scale?

yes, you can't use timestamps
if it's periodic time sampling (i.e., every hour or whatever) and you don't think the patters are a function of time: you shoud just omit it
otherwise, there are feature engineering approaches... some ideas: time of day, day of week, month of year, etc; or for irregularly sampled time series, "change in time since last time step" etc
thanks @AlexDBlack , actually I am using the change time, but the scope of change time also can't be anticipated

in that situation: unless you have a reason to prefer one or the other (based on knowledge of the dataset), I'd personally start with change in time (between time steps - then normalize, of course) plus some basic feature engineering based on absolute timestamps (time of day etc)

Could you suggest some dropout?
When I set dropout to 0 it means it is not performing dropout?
yes
0.0 means - no dropout

that depends
@papperwing https://github.com/deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j/blob/master/deeplearning4j-nn/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/nn/conf/NeuralNetConfiguration.java#L962-L972
0.5 is usually the place to start, and is what tends to be used most commonly in practice
One more question. When I set dropout for whole network (for example from zoo) will it change dropout setting for layers which has already dropout set?
I set it in FineTuneConfiguration
anything set after .list() or .graphBuilder() will override the global (pre list/graphBuilder) setting
same as with fine tune - or at least it should be
i.e., finetune is global, but override on specific layers if you want
Remember dl4j wants an inverted dropout value.
So if you want 40% dropout you need to give it 0.6
(Its the probability of _retaining_ an activation, not the probability of dropping it)
Cool thanks :D I thought it is exactly opposit :D
0.5 is save than :D
Yes exactly, I was a bit confused by it as well.
With 0.5 it makes no difference, but once you deviate from that it makes a huge diff.

That's great. Are there any significant differences between LSTM and GravesLSTM? I've built a system with a few models (and a "voting" system) to classify text data, I'm wondering if including an extra classifier based on LSTM makes any sense. If they are both expected to work well on similar data, I'm not sure if there's a reason to do so.

My RNN classifier configuration is based on [this](https://github.com/deeplearning4j/dl4j-examples/blob/master/dl4j-examples/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/examples/recurrent/word2vecsentiment/Word2VecSentimentRNN.java#L74-L85).

I'd bet the answer is "it depends". : P I guess what I'm asking is - should I expect any significant differences between two models built with LSTM and GravesLSTM layers using similar hyperparameters? Or will the differences be no more significant than between two models with GravesLSTM layers built with different seeds?
I think the plain LSTM is significantly faster to train on GPU.
I see. Is the training performance the only significant difference or are there different use cases for these layers?
I think our GravesLSTM uses peep connections? I think it can perform better with the same amount of training iterations.
@wmeddie So basically you're trading training speed on GPU for the need to feed more data or use more epochs, but the overall performance should be roughly the same?

To be honest - I was wondering if there are any theoretical differences, like one being easier to overfit than the other, to see if there is a reason to include another RNN classifier in my project. I guess I'll just try using LSTM and check the results in practice.

@czyzby re: LSTM vs. GravesLSTM - they are similar, latter has peephole connections. See javadoc for more details
I'd recommend using the first - it supports cudnn, the latter doesn't (just need to add deeplearning4j-cuda-8.0 to your project to use it) - both were added post 0.8.0 fyi

having a clue, that you need x layers with y1 neurons on level 1, y2 on layer 2, .. etc to detect something analyzing a 64x256 pixel image is a big gain
the main goal on that is not to set a parameters to a random weight but use a weights from other trained models
it doesnt matter if your criteria is jeniffer, hello kitty or an integrated circuit
this is the "decission making part"
ok, so we can use any pre-trained model
for any new task
basically yes
or you can calculate it from scratch
the problem is: you have to choose a structure and some training oparameters before you can do calculations

When I work with multiDataset, having multiple different loss functions. How does the lossfunction look like?
total loss
I specify loss for each output node.
but what is relationship between them
@snurkabill multiple loss functions requires multiple output layers (or loss layers). The losses for each are simply added
@AlexDBlack  I understand. but what is math behind it? how to express total loss function?

the loss reported by the net is simply:
LossTotal = avgOverExamples(Loss1) + ... + avgOverExamples(LossN) + l1RegularizationComponent + l2RegularizationComponent

Hi, the documentation of Doc2Vec says "The main purpose of Doc2Vec is associating arbitrary documents with labels, so labels are required". However, the approach described by Le and Mikolov ( https://cs.stanford.edu/~quocle/paragraph_vector.pdf ) allows to build paragraph vectors without any labels. Is this also possible with deeplearning4j?
@timoschick you're mixing the 2
it's for unsupervised document classification
what they mean "without labels" is it's not really a supervised process
people in practice tend to use it as a document classification system
but is it possible with deeplearning4j to obtain paragraph vectors as described in the above paper without knowing any labels?
So wait..
You realize you define vectors as vocab words and train on that right?
That's the whole point of the algo
@timoschick it just means - you will use random labels for each document
the labels are part of the vocab
nothing beyond that
right
technically - labels will exist
but you won't provide them
both options are possible for dl4j
aah ok!
thanks a lot :)
they just serve different purposes
@timoschick yeah if you look at the paper, compare word2vec to paragraph vectors
you end up having nearly the exact same algo
just trained slightly different

so if, for example, I want to use paragraph vectors in deeplearning4j to compute the distance of documents (as is done in Sec 3.3 of the paper by Le and Mikolov), I simply use some random labels for each document and then ignore them?
yes
d2v will provide you with random labels in that case
LabelsSource generates them
but you can also set them yourself
i.e. doc_1
doc_2
doc_3
etc
okay, perfect!

eclipse/deeplearning4j is the official repo / master

I cannot debug the above application on a linux machine where I can easily change code and iterate quickly. I have created a toy app based on one of the dl4j examples. There is no tomcat, it just loads the net built in CnnSentenceClassificationExample (I used the same training code there), then loops over the DataISetIterator and call net.output on each batch. 

I noticed that if logging Pointer.physicalBytes(), in the toy app it goes up until a certain point. Then there is a few second pause, and the totalBytes number drops. Once I see this happen, I see that it happens each time the value gets to a certain max value.

In the tomcat app logs, I don't see the value ever go down. I wasn't logging physical bytes when I saw the OOM, and will do more tests. But, I'm currently trying to pin down where in the dl4j, nd4j, javacpp code is running during this pause (which appears to be garbage collection for native memory). The OutOfMemory errors generally occur in <init>FloatPointer

@treo : regarding my prev post (stuck at model creation) I believe I run into the issue reported here: https://github.com/deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j/issues/6518   . If I run it with a pre-initialized model all works fine. Calling model.init on Tesla v100 with specific weight init causes it to crash. I will wait for a fix  and just use preinitialized models as a workaround.

@pandarhino oh, I wasn't aware of this one yet, usually when something hangs like that it is because nvidia has released something with a new gpu, and you are trying to use a cuda kernel that isn't compiled for it, and then the driver starts compiling all kernels, and that takes forever

@treo alternatively one could just remove the model.init() call ... not yet sure how that effects the learning in the long run, but for now it works. How are weights etc initialized if one does not call .init() at the very first initialization of the net?
@pandarhino well, they aren't - so you get the uninitialized memory state there - sometimes it is all zero, sometimes full of trash or remnants of some other computation of your current process

i don't see seed specified
where data comes from?
with spark it's more then possible to get data coming in different order

```
@raver119
it's called reproducibility
if you use same rng seed
and your data comes in the same order
you must get same result
```
see this? ^^^
order matters
lots of math operations are NOT commutative
and in spark environment you're dealing with RDD chunks
not a sequential stream like on your desktop
so if workers get data in different order - you'll be getting slightly different models
not a radically different, sure, but still different
however, it usually has very small effect on model quality
other factors are playing more important role there

- make sure libnd4j and nd4j checkout are sibling directories (i.e. have the same parent directory)

19:37:48.570 [main] INFO org.deeplearning4j.optimize.listeners.PerformanceListener - ETL: 0 ms; iteration 809; iteration time: 1 ms; samples/sec: 1000.000; batches/sec: 1000.000; score: 1.016634413099382;

@snurkabill it gives you two things: timing information and etl time. @raver119 And when someone will use my framework, it is restricting him to turn off gc too, isnt it?
no
that’s setting specific to nd4j-cuda only
Nd4j.getMemoryManager().setAutoGcWindow(2500);
set something like that before calling for fit()
it won’t affect anything but nd4j-cuda
you could completely disable it, but it’s not recommended  _yet_
and last thing, is how you feed nn
recommended way - to feed using DataSetIterator
in this case your iterator will be wrapped into async prefetch etc

This is a very general question since I'm just doing exploratory reading currently - the question is: to what extent does DL4J (and its associated components/dependencies) provide advanced linear algebra functionality in a CUDA-transparent (i.e. - no change to high level code across back-end switch)?
My example case is Cholesky decomposition of a (suitable) matrix.  It looks like the function exists down in BLAS (`Lapack. potrf`) and also in `MathUtils` (`org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition.choleskyFromMatrix`), but I'm not sure how to get at those given an nd4j matrix in a backend-transparent fashion.  Can I do this?  If so will it be CUDA accelerated in either (or both) cases?
If you can do it in nd4j it usually is cuda transparent, however,  especially the lapack stuff isn't quite as well developed if I remember correctly
I remember that there were attempts by some people to add proper lapack support, but I'm not sure if ever something came out of it.
and as they aren't really needed for dl4j itself there isn't really any pressure to implement them
With complex number support also having been dropped quite a while ago, I guess you wouldn't be using nd4j as a general purpose math library anyway

@treo The reason this came up was hyper-parameter optimization using a Guassian Process model, the implementation of which needs the Cholesky decomposition.  In a sense you can argue its not the DL itself, its the optimization of the hyper-parameters used in the DL.  However, if you're trying to build an automated system for training, having parts of it that have to hop back into Python-land is annoying.  Not strictly a killer, but annoying ;-)
Sure, I'm just trying to show were we are at currently
lapack support was added recently
like in 0.8.2
so, worth a check for methods availability

@SteveDraper Thanks to @rcorbish Cholesky decomposition is available in ND4J. There are a couple of unit tests showing how to use the methods: https://github.com/deeplearning4j/nd4j/blob/master/nd4j-backends/nd4j-tests/src/test/java/org/nd4j/linalg/api/blas/LapackTest.java#L61

Like this: MultiLayerConfiguration conf = new NeuralNetConfiguration.Builder()
            .seed(seed)
            .iterations(iterations)
            .regularization(false).l2(0.005) // tried 0.0001, 0.0005
            .activation(Activation.RELU)
            .learningRate(0.0001) // tried 0.00001, 0.00005, 0.000001
            .weightInit(WeightInit.XAVIER)
            .optimizationAlgo(OptimizationAlgorithm.STOCHASTIC_GRADIENT_DESCENT)
            .updater(Updater.RMSPROP).momentum(0.9)
            .list()
            .layer(0, convInit("cnn1", channels, 50 ,  new int[]{5, 5}, new int[]{1, 1}, new int[]{0, 0}, 0))
            .layer(1, maxPool("maxpool1", new int[]{2,2}))
            .layer(2, conv5x5("cnn2", 100, new int[]{5, 5}, new int[]{1, 1}, 0))
            .layer(3, maxPool("maxool2", new int[]{2,2}))
            .layer(4, new DenseLayer.Builder().nOut(500).build())
            .layer(5, new OutputLayer.Builder(LossFunctions.LossFunction.NEGATIVELOGLIKELIHOOD)
                .nOut(numLabels)
                .activation(Activation.SOFTMAX)
                .build())
            .backprop(true).pretrain(false)
            .setInputType(InputType.convolutional(height, width, channels))
            .build();

Hello, I have a question : I have a big dataset of 800Mo to train, and I split it up in 50 small datasets, and I would like to know if I am doing a net.fit() one by one on each small datasets, would it work like if I've done a net.fit() on this big dataset ?

50 DataSet objects? or 50 different DataSetIterators?

So, I have a corpus of 100.000 lines of sentences, and I created INDArrays with it, Input and output, then I create a DataSet of (input,output) but this dataset is too big, so I decided to split this corpus in small corpus to create small datasets, because I cannot find a datasetiterator which would be convenient for my case
So, it's 50 DataSet objects :)

ok, so the thing with fitting from 50 datasets directly (as in .fit(DataSet)) is that's your minibatch size - i.e., those aren't split up internally or anything
now, if have 50 DataSet objects with 100000/50 = 2000 examples each, it'll give you identical results as a DataSetIterator with minibatch size 2000 (and the same order of presenting examples)
if you want a smaller minibatch size (2000 is certainly on the large side) one of many options it to export a bunch of smaller ones to disk (DataSet.save(File)), and use FileDataSetIterator to load them

Hi everyone,
I'm currently experimenting with CNN for image segmentation and I found an interesting article https://arxiv.org/pdf/1302.1690.pdf describing potential speed boost using new approach named MaxPoolingFragments.
In classic approach we are using sliding window - the limitation of this approach is, that each max-pooling layer decreases the image resolution. I would like to experiment with described approach, and try to inplement it using Dl4j.
The scheme can briefly be described like this:
An additional dimension called "fragments" is introduced.
Convolutional layers compute the convolution on each input fragment and thus outputs the same amount of fragments as it got from the input.
Max-pooling layers are applied to each input fragment by computing fragments for each offset of the max-pooling kernel, and thus increases the amount of fragments. Example: a 2x2 max-pooling layer would produce 4 output fragments with the kernel offset by (0,0), (0,1), (1,0), and (1,1) (cartesian product of two sets (0.. k-1))

Since I only have little experience with the Dl4j framework, I would like to start a discussion on, whether such a scheme could be implemented as an extension of Dl4j or if major structural changes would be needed? If it is possible as an extension, I would be glad to dig further into the details and develop the extension.

Okay, thanks for your help,  I've got it working and got it to calculate the correct determinant on an example by using the 1.0.0-alpha version of nd4j-native-platform

Thank-you both for your help @raver119 and @AdamGibson

Here is the code (in Scala):

```
import org.nd4j.linalg.api.ndarray.INDArray
import org.nd4j.linalg.factory.Nd4j
import org.nd4j.linalg.api.ops.DynamicCustomOp


object example_calc_determinant extends App {
  println("Hello, World!")
  val d: Int=2
  val seed: Int=1234
  val m = Nd4j.rand(Array[Int](d,d), seed)
  var result:INDArray = Nd4j.createUninitialized(1)
  val op = DynamicCustomOp.builder("matrix_determinant")
    .addInputs(m)
    .addOutputs(result)
    .build
  Nd4j.getExecutioner.exec(op)
  println("determinant is:")
  println(result)
}
```

normally a .setInputType(InputType.convolutionalFlat(...)) is all you need for that... it adds a preprocessor to do the reshaping
Not sure why that would fail with multiple epochs though (should be fine) - mind filing an !issue?

@AlexDBlack 
> normally a .setInputType(InputType.convolutionalFlat(...)) is all you need for that... 

Great hint, I’ll try that.

> Not sure why that would fail with multiple epochs though (should be fine) - mind filing an !issue? 

I used it incorrectly, and misread the error to be multi-epoch-related although it was not. By using the batch size when reshaping with `ds.features = ds.features.reshape(batchSize, 1, 28, 28)`, the last batch of the epoch had fewer records, which caused an error.  I could fix it by using the record count of the mini-batch instead of a fixed batch size: `ds.features = ds.features.run{reshape(shape()[0], 1, 28, 28)}`.

I use yolo2,  reference to ObjectDetectionRecordReader, it should be one-hot and classification
object detection is definitely *not* standard classification
so how to get label index from training dataset?
in object detection

OK, so what you need:
```
INDArray classLabels = labels.get(NDArrayIndex.all(), NDArrayIndex.interval(4,4+numClasses), NDAraryIndex.all(), NDArrayIndex.all())
INDArray labelPresentMask = classLabels.sum(1);
INDArray idxs = Nd4j.argMax(classLabels, 1);
```

note that idxs is 3d [minibatch, h, w] as obviously for object detection you don't necesarily have an object at every x/y location.
also note that labelPresentMask has 1 if object is present at that (x,y) or 0 otherwise
indx is all labels in current batch? how can I get label I had marked for current dataset ?

if you want a specific example, just use a .get(point(x), all(), all()) on those arrays

as per everything in DL4J - the leading dimension always indexes the example in the minibatch
so x would be the example number

So going through and processing my data myself end to end I have been working with the concept of collapsing dimensional information. For instance my data (after being normalized) has a lot of Boolean, Gaussian, and word scalar(Manhattan) data, problem being that combining all 3 causes the data to bump from 1D to 2D due to the word scalar. So working with this I collapse the word scalar to 1D and append it in location expanding the INDArray.

To accomplish this so far I have had to keep a String array to keep track of the indexs of what "feature" (essentially index in the array is index in the INDArray) while the string is referenced as a key in a Hashmap as I needed access to sub feature names (but sadly this makes me lose order) so i can collapse dimensions.

So when collapsing this 2D data to 1D data I have found it would drastically easier in an INDArray conceptually wise.... but INDArrays don't store strings from what i can tell

Am i mistaken on INDArrays being able to hold strings and what are some different approaches if you guys know any to collapsing data?

@thorsanvil you are correct, it's numerical only in INDArrays
string NDArrays are being added in some of the work we're currently doing, but that doesn't help you now (should be in the next release I think?)
as for mapping the array entries back to your data inputs - unfortunately we don't really have tools for that, so it's necessarily a manual process

I am trying to get a basic implementation of Federated Learning (FL) for a neural network together using dl4j. As I understand FL, the idea is that we:
1. Train multiple models  on small distinct training sets (known as *local models*)
2. Compute a single *global model* by averaging the weights of all the local models
3. Replace the local models for the global model and then repeat from step 1. for some amount of iterations. 

The idea being that  we this way get a model that reflects the union of the training data without having to collect the all the training sets centrally (a privacy feature).

@DaGump you can configure the backend it uses with cpu priority..beyond that we need to allow people to specify cpu /gpu workspaces to use

@DaGump that's not possible because of the JVM
right now we load one set of libnd4j binaries in to the JVM at a time..this is mainly for maintainability purposes
we reuse a ton of code across different backends
the "right" way to do this will be to have the cuda backend support cpu allocation with proper workspaces
my "workaround" would be to run your program twice

once with gpu once with gpu and cpu with cpu set as higher priority
that way it's just flags you set
that will also stop you from reconfiguring the pom manually
it's not quite the ideal version of what you want but it's close enough for now

ok, so the problem here is the fact that when you downsample, the output length doesn't match the input length
so, if you have input sequence length 100, then downsample by 2x, your output is now 50 steps (i.e., 100/2)
you're using the wrong label length in your code, in other words
that isn't being picked up in validation, hence the exception isn't helpful...

`SamplingDataSetIterator` exists in two packages, with slightly different code:
- [nd4j](https://github.com/eclipse/deeplearning4j/blob/master/nd4j/nd4j-backends/nd4j-api-parent/nd4j-api/src/main/java/org/nd4j/linalg/dataset/api/iterator/SamplingDataSetIterator.java)
- [deeplearning4j](https://github.com/eclipse/deeplearning4j/blob/master/deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j-data/deeplearning4j-utility-iterators/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/datasets/iterator/SamplingDataSetIterator.java)

The code in `nd4j` seems more up to date than in `deeplearning4j` (`asyncSupported()` returns `true`, supports sampling with replacement, applies preprocessor in `next()` ). I guess, that you don't plan to maintain both of them. Which one shall I use in my code?
Thanks in advance.

@AlexDBlack  I didn't ask the right question, but finally, I figured out that `DataSet.sample(int numSamples, org.nd4j.linalg.api.rng.Random rng, boolean withReplacement)` and `ViewIterator` is what I need. I want to run multiple evaluations of my model to estimate test result variances. I will randomly subsample the held-out test set, each time.
Oops I didn't mean to press enter. I wanted to format that better.
@webegit1234 it depends on what you want to do. If you simply want to make a prediction, at each time step, based on a complete time series, just use .output
rnnTimeStep is only necessary if you don't have the complete time series available when generating predictions
and hence want to make predictions 1 or N steps at a time, taking into account the past history/state
read this, if you haven't already: https://deeplearning4j.org/usingrnns#rnntimestep
@AlexDBlack To best explain what I'm trying to do, say I'm trying to predict the stock market and I trained with 30 time steps of past data. I want to be able to predict the next 30 days.

in that case, it depends on your network configuration
one approach (and, the one that I would probably recommend) is to use a multi-task network: that is, at each step, predict T+1, T+2, ..., T+30

you can potentially generate predictions and feed them back in *as if they were real inputs* - but that will likely perform less well, especially for long time horizons for the predictions (also google beam search, if you consider this approach)

in the former case, you have 30 outputs, and use rnnTimeStep once for each new step of data. in the latter case, you have 1 output, and use rnnTimeStep 30 times for each new piece of data (being careful to reset back to the past state)
@AlexDBlack Thanks Alex. This is good info.

@agibsonccc @raver119 Hi both, I'm still confuse about the ParallelWrapper.  According to the website "your initial model will be duplicated, and each worker will be training its own model. After every X iterations, defined by averagingFrequency(X), all models will be averaged, and training will continue after that."  My question is that how will this process speed up the training speed?  I did some test on my data, by implementing PW, it takes a little bit longer to train the network (without modify the nEpochs number), however the result is better.  So I assuming that the way PW speed up the training process is by reducing the nEpochs number?  For example if the original epochs = 100, I can now get a similar result if I reduce it to 50 but implement PW and set the workers=2?  Am I understand right?
that's one of possible modes, yes
and perfomance is relative to iteration time vs averaging time
Ok, thanks.
and then there's os nuances: i.e. on windows you can't have p2p between gpus, so averaging will happen i host memory.
there's also gradients sharing mode available in pw
you can read about it here: !spark
second link
it works the same way without spark, via parallelwrapper
ok, thanks a lot!
and it's usually faster
but there's the same logic behind: if your iteration time is microscopic - it will be waste of time trying to parallelize training
this limitation is widely known as `Amdahl's law`
sure

hi @AlexDBlack  I found this old ticket about adding about a MemoryMappedDataSetIterator  that would allow shuffling on the fly, even with serialized DataSet-like objects, cf. https://github.com/deeplearning4j/nd4j/issues/1521. It's still open but it's a very old ticket. Is there any plan to implement something like this? @daanvdn one option is to use FileDataSetIterator with smaller DataSet objects
https://github.com/eclipse/deeplearning4j/blob/master/deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j-data/deeplearning4j-utility-iterators/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/datasets/iterator/file/FileDataSetIterator.java#L35-L38
so for minibatch 64, you could (for example) save DataSets of size 8, and then FileDataSetIterator will randomly combine 8 of them (8x8=64) to get the required minibatch size
also depending on the data source, preprocessing to MapFile can work, then just train as normal from that
https://github.com/deeplearning4j/dl4j-examples/blob/master/dl4j-examples/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/examples/dataexamples/MapFileConversion.java

right, iterators in general are local only
for spark, data feeding can work in exactly the same way though
i.e., DataSet object size < minibatch 64 results in shuffling within each minibatch
otherwise you only get shuffling of minibatch order by default (if DataSet size == minibatch size)

so if I call `org.deeplearning4j.spark.impl.multilayer.SparkDl4jMultiLayer#fit(java.lang.String)` and set the requested miniBatchSize to e.g. 64   and my files are size 8, it would work out of the box?

Returning to my question from couple of days ago: I need to be able to freeze some weights in NN during training. Like "first weight of second neuron in third layer", to exclude this weight from tweaking during backpropagation. So far I've come up only with one idea: I should implement my own activation function (extending some existing one), where I'll override `backprop` method to skip some weights based on my criteria. The problem is that there' only `INDArray in and  `INDArray epsilon` as inputs there, so I have no idea about what layer it is and what neuron.
Any ideas on how to go further? Or maybe suggestion on other approaches?

@dtitov that's a *very* specific use case. Is there a paper you're referencing somewhere? Beyond that...yeah you're not too far off. You'd have to prevent it from updating certain things based on your own custom triggers. I would say a custom layer/vertex would be better than an activation function.

@agibsonccc Well, it's referenced in many places where lifetime learning is considered. You can take a look here: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.07569.pdf (e.g. page 8, Figure 2c: "Selective retraining"). There's a need in freezing some weights and not nececcerily the wole layers, but just some specific weights here and there.

- training time, number of parameters which would be high for no reason

i just change the batchsize var?

ah, well, CSV example uses splitTestAndTrain

Hello, how to properly load large datasets ( over 20gb of data, 90m sampls) ?
If i load it in straight way it takes to long time to load (actualy it did not finished after several hours)
```
    val dataSet = DataSet()  
    dataSet.load(File(datasetPath))  
    val miniBatches = MiniBatchFileDataSetIterator(dataSet, batchSize)  
    return MultipleEpochsIterator(epoches, miniBatches)  
```
I saw MiniBatchFileDataSetIterator(DataSet baseData, int batchSize, boolean delete, File rootDir) constructor which saves individual batches to individual files, but did not found any constructor which does the opposite - loads all those chunks.

@frakc You could either use one of the existing implementations or simply implement your own `DataSetIterator` to load data incrementally. See https://github.com/holgerbrandl/deeplearning4j/tree/master/deeplearning4j-data/deeplearning4j-datasets/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/datasets/iterator/impl for examples.  

Since you seem to use kotlin already, see https://github.com/holgerbrandl/yelp_restaurant_labels/blob/master/src/main/kotlin/Helpers.kt#L170 for a kotlin example impl.  

When using a custom  `DataSetIterator` , the `MiniBatchFileDataSetIterator` may be omnitted (since it would just re-batch the data again).

For async pre-fetching see https://deeplearning4j.org/benchmark#etl--asynchronous-etl
@holgerbrandl @frakc that's actually the wrong recommendation

that's the part to focus on
@holgerbrandl read the !examples readme
those iterators were written before datavec
we have a few specialized ones that should become record readers (like the language generation one) but for 99% of tasks out of the box there is zero reason to do that

https://github.com/deeplearning4j/dl4j-examples/blob/master/dl4j-examples/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/examples/recurrent/seq2seq/AdditionRNN.java
so first indarray gets name of first input, etc

first array gets assotiates with name "additionIn", other one with "sumOut"

Hi there, I am using nd4j for inferencing in a web service, and I found System.gc() is frequently called in the gc.log. I'm pretty sure it has something to do with Nd4j, can someone tell me why `System.gc()` should be called?
@febtree have a look at the following page: !memory
and !workspaces
@AlexDBlack  Thanks for your reply. Since I'm not using workspace here, `Nd4j.getMemoryManager().togglePeriodicGc(false)` will help me turn off the periodic `System.gc()` call, right?
no
you're probably using it
if you're using neural networks
are you using cuda?
yes I'm using cuda, but I'm not using any neural networks, just some matrix multiplication with Nd4j
oh
you should use workspaces as much as possible then, to avoid reliance on java gc
https://github.com/deeplearning4j/dl4j-examples/blob/master/nd4j-examples/src/main/java/org/nd4j/examples/Nd4jEx15_Workspaces.java
check out these examples and comments there

Thanks, I'll take a look at the examples. The reason why workspace should be used is because JVM probably won't collect the garbages when the off-heap memory or the GPU memory is maxed out, which will lead out of memory error. Am I seeing it right?
no
the reason is explained on the page Alex linked above
if you're working with cyclic workloads with lifetime known in advance, there's no sense tracking them via gc
you should just allocate memory once, and reuse it
over and over again
that's what workspaces do

nd4j.getRandom() often produces the same sequence in a multithreaded environment. How to solve it?

@cqiaoYc 
> 
nd4j.getRandom() often produces the same sequence in a multithreaded environment. How to solve it?

Nd4j.getRandom() is based on a thread local design
i.e., each thread has its own state, seed, etc
if you want different values in different threads, use Nd4j.getRandom.setSeed(...) in each thread
@AlexDBlack thank you! I solved it by setting: random.setSeed(System.nanoTime()^System.currentTimeMillis());

@mequanent it's also normal in NLP tasks to not have *every* word - otherwise you have a very noisy corpus

While training the MultiLayerNetwork LeNet in `trainMultiLayerNetwork` works as expected (~1.8GB memory usage), the `trainComputationGraph` method throws `OutOfMemoryError` after the first epoch. Could someone have a look at the `mlpToCG` method, which is my very simple attempt to convert a MultiLayerConfiguration into a ComputationGraph?

looks about right

I'd suggest trying !workspaces
open an issue though, it would be good to try to track down the difference at some point
@AlexDBlack memory keeps allocating until OOM in the trainComputationGraph method while fitting. I'll try out workspaces and will report
@AlexDBlack Workspaces seemed to resolve the leak(?), thanks
@slang03 leak is the wrong word
That would mean we wrote code that doesn't free memory :D
GC references are just slower..you have to set a GC frequency
Yeah, I wasn't sure how to call it :D maybe rather uncontrolled allocation :D
workspaces mitigates most of it
but you'll notice we still set a trigger in there
for the gc window
JVM internals are finnicky :D
Won't argue there
You sure about that? MLN worked wouthout setting a workspace
Yes I'm very sure
We wrote workspaces for a reason
Simple problems by definition don't require thhem
but still makes things faster anyways
Okay, I'll trust you this time :D
Harder problems apply more GC pressure
it's not hard to wrap your head around there :D
I can give you a nice lecture in the gitter channel on the internals
or you can just take my word and stay awake
take your pick :D
But why does it have to do sth with GC frequency? Felt more like a never ending loop in memory allocation
Sure go ahead :)
if you have suggestions for the workspace docs that would make it more usable feel free to let us know
So workspaces actually creates 1 managed  buffer
which means less GC
whereas the "old" gc is all distributed, when you have less ram/off heap memory to play with + more allocations you end up losing a "race"
that race is whether you run out of configured memory or not
the problem here is System.gc() is a "suggestion"
it's not guaranteed to trigger
so it's harder to rely on
makes sense
so workspaces was about reducing allocations
so while fitting, we are allocating memory faster than gc can clean up? seems like a weak implementation of the gc
yep
well not really..the problem is we are doing everything off heap
the JVM has no way of controlling what we do there
we're using weak references from the JVM to track buffer references
we implement our own garbage collection and memory management
we're doing that for a variety of reasons
gpu/c++ raw pointers for faster compute, more stable latency, ..
databases that are written in java go in to similar territory

makes sense again. though why doesnt java offer an alternative gc when doing memory intensive stuff offheap? I bet deeplearning is not the only use case for that? as you said databases and I bet many more aswell?
Funny, we talked to the lead JDK people this morning at oracle
sounds more like you need to reinvent the wheel again and again for your specific terrain
oh really
yep
Main thing is cross platform quirks
and stability of compute
making "float" consistent across different platforms that conforms to a spec is a hard problem
so deep learning just has different needs
the JDK folks are trying
they know this is a new area
there's a few areas like project panama and metropolis that are making this better
but it's still green field
deep learning has different requirements than java does
java needs stability, DL can live with approximations
DL needs more speed
there's some middle ground we're negotiating there though
for now our best bet is to give library authors more knobs
which is what we're pushing for
okay seems plausible. maybe the growth of this project make them more aware of these needs and one can find a good compromise
yeah
we're the lead DL project on the JVM
that actually uses the full extent
we have our own JVM/JNI transpiler, off heap memory,..
all sorts of stuff going on under the hood
other frameworks that attempt to do this use SWIG usually and don't really integrate with it
whereas with us you can control all these low level knobs from java
kind of like how TF has a lot of functionality only in python
we're similar for java
that's where things like workspaces come from though
and these weird hacks you see
you're right to ask about it though :D
okay i think i get it :D
most folks just want it to work though
so we give 1 line explanations most of the time
like "turn this on"
should be sufficient for 99%
or "use this for faster speed and less memory"
yep
happy to go in to details though if you're curious
it's all out there in the oss for folks to look at
I'm not hiding anything. There are definitely things we aren't happy with
but we make it work anyways as best we can
i'm always happy to learn sth
great!
yeah its always a compromise
I wish I had more discussions like this
most of the time it's "what's maven" :D

@bradjohns94 yeah models aren't threadsafe
that's what parallelwrapper and parallelinference (snapshots/next release) are for
models have a ton of internal state like learning rate schedules and activations
updater state as well
yes, models are definitely NOT thread safe, and won't probably ever be. there's too many tricks used inside to  allow concurrency
ugh, no, you don't want that code
on cpu you might not see problems without debugger
but on cuda it'll be disaster
multi-gpu memory management & data locality handling is way more tricky then just .foreach() allows

@MichalKoszalka break down what the exception says, it's all there
> Input size (3 columns

that's what the network is actually getting, in terms of number of features

> does not match layer input size (layer # inputs = 4)

that's what you've configured the network for

so either your network configuration is wrong (nIn on first layer should be 3, for 3 features)
or your data pipeline is wrong

based on your parseSingleMonth method, it looks like you have 3 features and 1 label
which means you need nIn(3) on your first layer

every little hyper param matters
neural nets are only robust in the first place with more data

it's overkill and more error prone
harder to reproduce results

I have a tuning question if that's okay... My scores are varying quite wildly over iterations, which suggests my learning rate is too high. But my update:parameter ratios are much too low according to https://deeplearning4j.org/visualization, which suggests my learning rate is too low... Any ideas what I could do? Could it be a regularization problem?

It actually could be a batch balance problem. Each mini batch should ideally be a representative sample of the whole data set. If, for some reason, your batches have widely different characteristics, then seeing such fluctuations is to be expected
It's a binary classification problem with roughly equally frequent classes, so their characteristics shouldn't be too different? Would a larger batch size help?

it isn't necessarily only the label balance that you should take into consideration. You can also run into problems if you have a lot of very similar examples. 

A larger batch size might help. Being intimately familiar with your data, would help even more when trying to understand what is happening here

@Aubret 
> I doubt that cudNN is really loaded, even if I don't have any error

there's 2 reasons why you wouldn't get that warning logged
either you're not using CUDA backend (can't be loaded, etc)
or your logging configuration is bad (so you're just not seeing the warning that is logged)

> .activation(this.hiddenActivation)

what activation function specifically are you using?

I ask because CuDNN only supports tanh - that's a cudnn limitation, nothing we can do about it
so if you're not using tanh, then we fall back to the built-in implementation
thinking about it now, we should make that behaviour more obvious

@Aubret the other thing is put a few breakpoints in the LSTM class and see what's actually happening for you...
https://github.com/deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j/blob/master/deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j-nn/src/main/java/org/deeplearning4j/nn/layers/recurrent/LSTM.java#L62-L82
@Aubret I see that you're running the UI - how often do you collect updates for it? It can really slow down training

Actually... I could sort this one out... It seems the data had several missing fields across the files, therefore those fields were either interpreted as empty or null causing the code to crash... And this was happening for both sequence and mortality CSV files
For the sequence dataset, I went through its files, and deleted the records with missing fields

For the mortality dataset, instead of one line containing 0 or 1, it also had an extra empty line, which was also causing the code to crash. In this case, I rewrote each of the lines, but taking only the first line into consideration
This may help someone if they stumble upon the same issue in the future

@pertl  Would that bug explain why Javafx applications using dl4j / nd4j do not shut down normally?
@pertl https://github.com/deeplearning4j/nd4j/pull/2464#pullrequestreview-86528448
cool thanks :-)
probably 'yes' concerning javafx
if a thread does not react on interrupt() you can basically just shoot the process dead
since maven:exec has a timeout it will still terminate after 15secs but basically the thread will keep running forever
based on this post on SO it looks like InterruptedException is utilized by JavaFX (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35208251/javafx-threads-shutdown-upon-application-exit)
Appreciate that link thank you. I have resorted to `System.exit(0)` but well aware it is a bit harsh.
though you should not rely on Thread#stop() since it's deprecated for really long (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/16504140/thread-stop-deprecated)
all threads / daemon should cooperate when catching (InterruptedException) then all works out fine
any ThreadPoolExecutors (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ThreadPoolExecutor.html) that are running should be terminated via #shutdown() / #shutdownNow() on interruption

Greetings! Anyone have a Maven command to build dl4j on a Mac that excludes all the Cuda stuff? I cannot figure it out. :(

@timmolter 
Should be smth like this:
```
mvn -B -U clean install -pl '!deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j-cuda,!nd4j/nd4j-backends/nd4j-backend-impls/nd4j-cuda,!nd4j/nd4j-backends/nd4j-backend-impls/nd4j-cuda-platform,!deeplearning4j/deeplearning4j-cuda' -Dlibnd4j.platform=macosx-x86_64 -Djavacpp.platform=macosx-x86_64 -P native -Dmaven.test.skip=true
```
If you need mac without avx2...

If with avx2 then add
```
-Dlibnd4j.extension=avx2 -Djavacpp.extension=avx2
```

Hi, I have two quick questions:

I'm an absolute Java novice, but a machine I have to use only allows custom functionality written in Java (or rather, running on a JVM). Can I run the DL4J library purely on a JVM or do I need other system resources installed?
Also, I've seen DL4J offers a python api. Does the program then still run on the JVM, or will it require a python interpreter to run in that case?

@neuneck
> I'm an absolute Java novice, but a machine I have to use only allows custom functionality written in Java (or rather, running on a JVM). Can I run the DL4J library purely on a JVM or do I need other system resources installed? Also, I've seen DL4J offers a python api. Does the program then still run on the JVM, or will it require a python interpreter to run in that case?

DL4J is java + native code (which automatically gets downloaded). Only extra required install is CUDA (for GPUs only, obviously)
and we don't have a python API - closest is model import from Keras
